Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandfather notices his grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I sat at my cluttered desk, headset pressing into my ear, the clock ticking down the last hour of my shift. My sales numbers glared at me from the screen—still three short of the weekly target. Management’s emails echoed in my mind: “Push harder, don’t let up.” I dialed another number, rehearsing my pitch, but my thoughts kept drifting to the living room, where my grandson sat slumped on the couch, shoulders hunched, eyes fixed on the floor. He’d barely spoken at dinner, and I could sense the weight he carried, the kind of burden I recognized from my own youth. I wanted to go to him, to offer the comfort and guidance a grandfather should, to remind him that he wasn’t alone. But every minute away from the phone meant another missed opportunity, another step further from my quota. My heart tugged me toward my grandson, but my job demanded I stay put, voice cheerful and persistent, chasing sales. The two worlds pulled at me, each expecting more than I felt I could give.
